utterances: (As Esti Kuperman) It's expected.
(As Ronit Krushka) It's medieval.
(As Esti Kuperman) It's not mandatory.
Nobody gets beaten if they don't feel like it.
(As Ronit Krushka) What happened to you?
(As Esti Kuperman) Nothing.
You happened to me.
Stay with us.
Day to Day returns in a moment.
It was the worst season in 50 years.
We're going to have negative GDP growth of five to six, but we're going to have negative GDP growth every quarter of next year.
When you look at this quarter, the consumer is 70 percent of GDP.
That leaves retailing down five at least.
It's horrendous, it's terrible and it all comes back to the consumer.

Fourteen trillion in debt, a 101k instead of a 401k, exploding unemployment accelerating; we'll lose another half a million jobs this month; that'll bring it to 2.5 million jobs; unemployment goes to 10 percent by December of '09.
So, the consumer is just devastated.

An $8 trillion negative wealth effect from housing; consumer bankruptcy is dramatically on the rise, consumers falling behind on their credit card bills, their auto loans, their student loans, their home loans.
The consumer is completely inundated, and nothing good is going to happen in the near term.
OK, so maybe I was understating it a bit when I said lackluster.
Where did you get that 10-percent unemployment rate?
That is the forecast of our firm.
Our firm is forecasting 10 percent unemployment by December of '09.
Here are the bulletproof facts: Unemployment has exploded in the last four months dramatically.
We now have lost 1.9 million jobs.
This month, we'll lose a half a million jobs.
That'll bring it to 2.4 million jobs lost.
That'll bring your unemployment to about 6.9.

Our forecast is for 10 percent by December of '09, but that doesn't include millions of people on part-time work that want full-time work; it doesn't include the people who've dropped out of the labor force.
When you look at those numbers, you're then looking at 14 percent unemployment.
The word depression is not off the table.
The worst is yet to come, and we think the Obama plan will do very little - do more negative than plus.
So, we don't really see anything good happening.
OK.
Well, I'm going to try to wrest some bright spots from you.
Online, it did fairly well.
Amazon said this was their best holiday season ever.
Let's talk about online.
It really did not do well.
Amazon clearly is best in class, and they did OK.
Interestingly enough, they didn't give out any sales numbers.
I'm a little suspicious about that.
I'm sure Amazon did OK, but let's look at the online sector.
For five years, they've increased at the rate of 20-to-25 percent and clearly are the strongest sector in the retail space.

However, this quarter, they will be flat to down one percent as a sector, still better than everything else, but I would say, when you've got a trend and when you're up 20 to 25 and you're flat to down one, that doesn't look too good to me.
Now, there are winners out there, of course.
The consumer is trading down.
So, we've closed 600 Starbucks stores, and Mrs. Fields Cookies is in bankruptcy; Ponderosa is in bankruptcy; Steak & Ale liquidated; Bennigan's liquated; casual bonding terrible.
But McDonalds hitting the ball out of the park, because it's cheap and good: coffee, $2 less than Starbucks.
They're winning.
Family Dollar, winning.
It's Wal-Mart time; they're winning.
Dollar Tree, winning.
The consumer doesn't have money so they are dramatically trading down.
Retail analyst Howard Davidowitz, thank you.
Thank you for the invite.
(Soundbite of music)
There's more to come on Day to Day from NPR News.
From NPR News, it's Day to Day.
The economy is doing so badly now that the number of new homes being built fell nearly 20 percent last month, and that is the biggest decline in a generation.
Nevada used to see new homes going up every day.
Now, it has the nation's highest foreclosure rate.
Producer Katia Dunn was in Nevada recently.
She says it reminded her of another disaster she covered.
A few months ago, I covered Hurricanes Ike and Gustav.
One thing I noticed about reporting a natural disaster: I felt like I should interview literally everyone I ran into on the street.
Everyone's life was touched by the hurricane.
I had the same feeling reporting on the housing crisis in Las Vegas.
Nearly half the homes there are under water, meaning homeowners owe more on their houses than they're worth.
If the people we met weren't in danger of losing their own house, they were involved in other ways.
In fact, it was so easy to find people caught up in the housing crisis, at one point, we simply walked up and down the street, knocking on doors and talking to people.
But there is one giant difference between people who are living through a financial disaster and those who are living through a natural one.
Ms.
DEANA O'REEHR (Loan Consultant, Las Vegas, Nevada): People do not want to talk about it.
They do not want to talk about their situation at all.
Deana O'Reehr(ph) is a loan consultant.
She helps people in foreclosure.
Often when people run into trouble, she says, their instinct is to hide.
They don't want to confess that they didn't make their payments or made a bad investment.
O'Reehr is also fighting to keep her own home.
She says the company unlawfully took over her property, and it helped, she says, when she tells people they're not alone.
Ms.
O'REEHR: I basically, immediately, tell them my story.
I say, you know what?
I'm there.
I've been there for year.
I owe so much money, it's not even funny.
I just tell them my realness, and then they usually will open up.
It's embarrassing, too.
It's really embarrassing.
That was Israel Twilly(ph).
He moved to Las Vegas a few years ago to retire.
He and his wife are now under water on their house and struggling to make the payments.
He's gone back to work.
He explained to us that one of the hardest parts of this situation is just admitting it, even to his family.

Because when you've got grandkids that depend on you, they always want Grandma and Granddad to bring around Christmas presents, and the kids, you know, they expect - even though they're grown, they still expect Christmas presents.
So, it's embarrassing, you know, not to be able to do it.
I worked with reporter Yuki Noguchi on this story.
She thinks that another reason people can't quite bring themselves to face this problem is that it's not over.
I don't think it's that people aren't willing to talk; I don't think they know who to talk to.
And you know, a lot of them just are fearful of hopelessness.
You know, they're afraid that if they reach out and talk to somebody, that they're going to be told they're going to lose their home.
And so, they'd rather just hunker down and hope for the best.
After a real natural disaster hits, people start putting their lives back together.
In Las Vegas, people wake up and face a crisis every day.
It's not exactly like a financial hurricane passed through this city.
It's more like hurricane season is just getting started.
Katia Dunn, NPR News.
(Soundbite of music)
(Laughter) Yes, yes.
Very much so - and my Protestant upbringing.
But, you know, that's what I love about my job the most - is diving into worlds that, you know, I would never otherwise be privy to.
And this one is particularly insular at times.
So to be invited into it by so many members of the Orthodox community, in both Los Angeles and London, where I did, you know, the bulk of the research, was just a really extraordinary experience.
Rachel Weisz, you grew up in a Jewish home in London but not an orthodox Jewish home.
I wonder if it was important to you that this community not be portrayed as a stereotype.
I mean, yeah.
I grew up, you know, very non-religious - I would say more like culturally Jewish.
But it was clear from the novel that this film wasn't pitting orthodoxy or religion against sexual freedom.
It was just saying this is a huge existential conundrum.
What do you do if you're orthodox, and you want to express your gay sexuality?
So Sebastian Lelio likes to say the antagonist is within, you know.
So he doesn't tell stories where you can locate wrongdoing in any one character.
I have to ask you about that six-minute scene that a lot of people are talking about.
The synagogue?
(Laughter) I was thinking of the hotel room but...
(Laughter) Right, of course.
It's vivid and intimate and moving.
So often as an actor, you're trying to ask yourself when the sex scene comes along, you know, is this in the script?
Is this gratuitous?
Why does this need to be here?
And how do we make it matter - or at least make it original?
And this had both.
Sebastian, he talked to us a lot about this scene.
And he sort of choreographed it like it was a dance really.
I mean, he even storyboarded it.
And it was important to him that we felt the history between these two characters through this scene.
So he made, you know, the moves we did very particular to these characters.
Nothing was frivolous.
And for both of them, it's such an emotional scene.
They've been waiting so long to reunite.
And, you know, it's - the whole scene is symbolic of Rachel McAdams's character's emancipation and release into existential freedom.
I mean, you know, there are sex scenes in films which can be meaningless.
And I think this is one of the more meaningful scenes in the film and definitely the most meaningful sex scene I've ever done.
There's actually no nudity.
I'm sorry to let the listeners down.
(LAUGHTER)
Yeah, it's true.
Rachel McAdams, what does Ronit's return set off in Esti beyond the chemical attraction we've noted?
It's really the catalyst for her whole life changing and challenging everything she's tried to suppress.
I think she thought she was just going to get through life and love her rabbi husband and, you know, obey all the rules.
But, you know, she just can't go on like that.
She really is kind of dying inside.
And so I think reaching out to Ronit is like reaching out for life - embracing the life preserver.
Rachel Weisz, you started modeling at the age of 14.
How did that happen?
I mean, I was in London, and I think I got, you know, scouted by someone.
Yeah, and they used to dress me up in makeup and make me look like I was 30 years old, and I was 15.
And I would say that I definitely experienced objectification firsthand in that period.
But in this story, what's extraordinary about Sebastian Lelio as a director is the way he subjectifies women and people.
Did you like my segue from modeling to ""Disobedience""?
I'm not even going to try and dangle a question about, you know, figure skating to Rachel McAdams.
You'll always be my figure skater though - you know that, right?
(Laughter) Aw.
Because her life would have been a different light - your life would have been a different life.
Very different, yes.
My knees were always knocking on the ice and yet somehow the stage wasn't as terrifying.
Just all that practice after school - no, I mean, a hard life.
Yeah, those morning practices - (laughter) a real killer, yeah.
